review.title: NuMVC: An Efficient Local Search Algorithm for Minimum Vertex Cover
review.abstract: The Minimum Vertex Cover (MVC) problem is a prominent NP-hard combinatorial optimization problem of great importance in both theory and application. Local search has proved successful for this problem. However, there are two main drawbacks in state-of-the-art MVC local search algorithms. First, they select a pair of vertices to exchange simultaneously, which is time-consuming. Secondly, although using edge weighting techniques to diversify the search, these algorithms lack mechanisms for decreasing the weights. To address these issues, we propose two new strategies: two-stage exchange and edge weighting with forgetting. The two-stage exchange strategy selects two vertices to exchange separately and performs the exchange in two stages. The strategy of edge weighting with forgetting not only increases weights of uncovered edges, but also decreases some weights for each edge periodically. These two strategies are used in designing a new MVC local search algorithm, which is referred to as NuMVC. We conduct extensive experimental studies on the standard benchmarks, namely DIMACS and BHOSLIB. The experiment comparing NuMVC with state-of-the-art heuristic algorithms show that NuMVC is at least competitive with the nearest competitor namely PLS on the DIMACS benchmark, and clearly dominates all competitors on the BHOSLIB benchmark. Also, experimental results indicate that NuMVC finds an optimal solution much faster than the current best exact algorithm for Maximum Clique on random instances as well as some structured ones. Moreover, we study the effectiveness of the two strategies and the run-time behaviour through experimental analysis.

metadata.title: NuMVC: An Efficient Local Search Algorithm for Minimum Vertex Cover

sections.text: The Minimum Vertex Cover (MVC) problem is a prominent NP-hard combinatorial optimization problem of great importance both in theory and application. Local search has proven successful for this problem. However, there are two main disadvantages of modern local MVC search algorithms: First, they select a pair of corners to replace them simultaneously, which is time consuming. Second, although these algorithms use edge weighting techniques to diversify the search, there are no mechanisms to reduce the weights. To address these problems, we propose two new strategies: two-step replacement and edge weighting with forgetfulness. The two-step replacement strategy selects two corners to exchange separately and performs the exchange in two stages. The strategy of edge weighting with forgetfulness not only increases the weights of uncovered edges, but also decreases some weights for each edge at regular intervals.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Minimum Vertex Coverage (MVC) can be considered as three different forms of the problem, from the standpoint of practical application. (V, E) Minimum Vertex Coverage (MVC) can be considered as three different problem areas. (V, E) Minimum Vertex Coverage (VLSI) can be a subset of S & V, so that each edge in G has at least one endpoint in S. MVC is an important combinatorial optimization problem with many real-world applications, such as network security, scheduling, VLSI design and industrial machine assignment. It is equivalent to two other known combinatorial optimization problems: the Maximum Independent Set (MIS) problem and the Maximum Clique (MC) problem, whichc © 2013 AI Access Foundation, VLSI Access Foundation and industrial machine assignment. sections.heading: 4. Edge Weighting with Forgetting
sections.text: In this section we introduce a new edge weighting called edge weighting with forgetfulness, which therefore plays an important role in NuMVC.The proposed strategy of edge weighting with forgetfulness works as follows: Each edge is associated with a positive integer number, and each edge weighting is referred to as one (s), but in each iteration the edge weighting of the uncovered edges is increased by a factor of 0 and 1. Note that edge weighting in the local search, including the one in this paper, is the more general streamlining idea for optimization problems based on Morris's breakout method (Morris, 1993) and in the local search for algorithms for contrint optimization problems such as SAT (Yugami, Ohta, Hara, 1994).

sections.heading: 6. Empirical Results
sections.text: In this section we present a detailed experimental study to evaluate the performance of NuMVC against standard benchmarks in the literature, i.e. the DIMACS and BHOSLIB benchmarks. First, we present the DIMACS and BHOSLIB benchmarks and describe some preliminary results of the experiments. Afterwards, we divide the experiments into three parts. The purpose of the first part is to present the performance of NuMVC in detail; the second part is to compare NuMVC with state-of-the-art heuristic algorithms; and the last part is to compare NuMVC with exact state-of-the-art algorithms.

sections.heading: 6.1 The Benchmarks
sections.text: We use the two standard benchmarks in MVC research (MIS, MC), the DIMACS benchmark and the BHOSLIB benchmark. The DIMACS benchmark includes examples from the industry and those generated by different models, while the BHOSLIB instances are random ones with a high degree of difficulty.

sections.heading: 6.1.1 DIMACS BENCHMARK
sections.text: The DIMACS benchmark is taken from the second DIMACS Implementation Challenge for the Maximum Clique Problem (1992-1993) 2. Thirty-seven charts were selected by the organizers for a summary to show the effectiveness of algorithms that comprise the second DIMACS Challenge Test Problems. These instances were generated from real-world problems such as coding theory, error diagnosis, Keller's guess and the Steiner Triple Problem, etc., as well as random charts in various models, such as the Brock and Hat families, ranging from less than 50 corners and 1,000 edges to more than 4,000 corners and 5,000,000 edges. Although proposed two decades ago, the DIMACS benchmark remains the most popular benchmark and is widely used to evaluate heuristic algorithms for MVC (Richter et al, 2007; Pullan et al, 2009; Cai et al, 2011; Gajurel & Bielefeld, 2012).

sections.heading: 6.1.2 BHOSLIB BENCHMARK
sections.text: The BHOSLIB3 (Benchmarks with Hidden Optimum Solutions, 2008; Cai al VC) instances were randomly generated in the area of phase transition according to the RB model (Xu & Li, 2006) and in practice (Xu & Li, 2000; Xu, Boussemart, Hemery, & Lecoutre, 2007).The SAT version of the BHOSLIB benchmark is widely used in the SAT contests both theoretically and practically (Xu & Li, 2000; Xu, Boussemart, Hemery, & Lecoutre, 2007).Nevertheless, the SAT solvers are much weaker than the MVC solvers in these problems, which remains justified in view of the results of the SAT Competition 2011 on this benchmark. The BHOSLIB instance of the BHIS benchmark is famous for its hardness and influential enough to be recommended by the MVC community (MC, MIS).

sections.heading: 6.3 Performance of NuMVC
sections.text: In this section we report in detail on the development of NuMVC to the two benchmarks.

sections.heading: 6.3.1 PERFORMANCE OF NUMVC ON DIMACS BENCHMARK
sections.text: NuMVC finds optimal (or best known) solutions for 35 out of 37 DIMACS instances. Note that the two failed instances are broken diagrams. Furthermore, NuMVC is consistent among the 35 successful instances in 32 cases (i.e. in all 100 passes), 24 of which are solved in one second. Overall, the NuMVC algorithm performs excellently in the DIMACS benchmark, except for the broken diagrams. It is noteworthy that the broken diagrams are artificially designed to defeat greedy heuristics by integrating explicitly low vertices into the optimal vertex coverage. In fact, most algorithms that favor higher-grade vertices such as GRASP, RLS, k-opt, COVER, and EWCC have also failed in these diagrams.

sections.heading: 6.3.2 PERFORMANCE OF NUMVC ON BHOSLIB BENCHMARK
sections.text: In Table 2, we illustrate the performance of NuMVC on the BHOSLIB benchmark. NuMVC successfully solves all BHOSLIB instances in terms of finding an optimal solution, and the size of the worst solution it finds never exceeds V C * + 1. NuMVC finds optimal solutions with a 100% success rate for 33 of these 40 instances, and the average success rate over the remaining 7 instances is 82.57%. These results are dramatically better than the existing results in the literature on this benchmark. NuMVC also finds a suboptimal solution of size V C + 1 for all BSHOSLIB instances very quickly, always in less than 30 seconds. This indicates that NuMVC can be used to solve the MVC problem efficiently even under a very limited time.In addition to the 40 BHOSLIB instances in Table 2, there is a challenging instance frb100-40 that has a vertex coverage that does not solve a hidden minimum coverage of the size 900 BOSLIB-3B Benchmark.

sections.heading: 6.4 Comparison with Other Heuristic Algorithms
sections.text: In the more recent literature, there are five leading heuristic algorithms for MVC (MC, MIS), including three MVC algorithms COVER (Richter et al., 2007), EWLS (Cai et al., 2010) and EWCC (Cai et al., 2011) and two MC algorithms DLS-MC (Pullan & Hoos, 2006) and PLS (Pullan, 2006). Note that EWCC and PLS are the improved versions of EWLS and DLS-MC, respectively, and perform better than their original versions on DIMACS and BHOSLIB benchmarks. Therefore, we compare NuMVC only with PLS, COVER and EWCC. When comparing NuMVC with other heuristic algorithms, we report V C, "suc," "time" and IQR. The average runtime over only successful runs ("suc time") cannot correctly state the comparative performance of algorithms, unless success rates are calculated by narrow.

sections.heading: 6.4.1 COMPARATIVE RESULTS ON DIMACS BENCHMARK
sections.text: The comparison results of the DIMACS benchmark are in Table 3. Most DIMACS instances are so simple that they can be solved by all solvers with a success rate of 100% within 2 seconds and are therefore not listed in the table. In fact, the fact that the DIMACS benchmark has been reduced to 11 useful instances really highlights the need for a new benchmark.9. http: / / www.nlsde.buaa.edu.cn / ˜ kexu / benchmarks / graph-benchmarks.htmAs in Table 3, NuMVC surpasses COVER and EWCC in all instances and is competitive and complementary to PLS. For the eight hard instances in which at least one solver does not achieve a success rate of 100%, PLS dominates on the broken diagrams, while NuMVC on the other, including the two supposedly most difficult instances C2000.9 and MANN a81 (et al, 2007; Groset al, so, CVC and CAL respectively, is very good in size of CR and 81).

sections.heading: 6.4.2 COMPARATIVE RESULTS ON BHOSLIB BENCHMARK
sections.text: In Table 4, we present comparison results on the BHOSLIB benchmark. To focus on the significant gaps in the comparisons, we do not report the results on the two groups of small instances (frb30 and frb35) that can be solved by all approaches within a few seconds. We consider the comparison between NuMVC and EWCC significantly better than the other algorithms on all BHOSLIB instances, both in terms of success rate and average runtime, which is also shown in Figure 1. We consider the comparison between NuMVC and EWCC as EWCC is obviously better than PLS and COVER on this benchmark.

sections.heading: 6.5 Comparison with Exact Algorithms
sections.text: In this section, we compare NuMVC with a state-of-the-art exact clique algorithm. Generally, exact algorithms and heuristic algorithms are rather complementary in their applications. Normally, exact algorithms find solutions for structured instances faster, while heuristic algorithms are faster on random ones.Compared toMVC + 2010b, much more precise algorithms are designed for the maximumClique problem (Carraghs & Pardalos, 1990; Fahle, 2002; O � sterga rd, 2002; Re � gin, 2003; Tomita & Kameda, 2009; Quan, 2010b, 2010b).The current industry-and-bound MC algorithm MaxCLQ (Li & Quan, 2010b), the MaxSAT inference technologies (Li, Manya, & Planes, 2007) to make significant advances.

sections.heading: 7. Discussions
sections.text: In this section, we will first examine the runtime distribution of NuMVC to some representative instances, and then the effectiveness of the two-step exchange strategy and forgetting mechanism in NuMVC. Finally, we will analyze the performance of NuMVC with different settings for its two forgetting mechanism parameters, which shows that NuMVC is not sensitive to these parameters.

sections.heading: 7.2 Effectiveness of Two-Stage Exchange
sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead.

sections.heading: 7.3 Effectiveness of the Forgetting Mechanism
sections.text: This year, we are talking about just under a million euros.

sections.heading: 7.4 Parameters for the Forgetting Mechanism
sections.text: The NuMVC algorithm has two parameters that specify the forgetfulness mechanism. Specifically, it examines how NuMVC performs with different settings on these two parameters and examines both DIMACS and BHOSLIB benchmarks. For the DIMACS benchmarks, we select the four instances that are used in the previous subsection for the same reasons. For the BHOSLIB benchmarks, we select frb53-24-2, frb56-25-2, which are of different sizes and appropriate hardness.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we have presented two new local search strategies for the problem of minimal vertex coverage (MVC), namely two-step replacement and edge weighting with forgetting. The two-step exchange strategy results in an efficient two-step operator for local MVC search algorithms, which significantly reduces the time complexity per step. On the basis of these two strategies, we have designed a light but effective local MVC search algorithm called NuMVC. The NuMVC algorithm has been evaluated against the most well-known heuristic algorithms for MVC (MC, MIS) on the basis of standard benchmarks, i.e. the DIMACS and BHOSLIB benchmarks provide only minor but effective results. Experimental results show that NuMVC is broadly competitive in terms of performance against other MACS benchmarks.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments

We thank the editor and anonymous reviewers for their valuable comments on earlier versions of this essay and Yanyan Xu for proofreading this essay.

referenceMentions.context: Due to their great importance in theory and applications, these three problems have been widely investigated for the last several decades (Carraghan & Pardalos, 1990; Evans, 1998; Pullan & Hoos, 2006; Richter, Helmert, & Gretton, 2007; Cai, Su, & Chen, 2010; Li & Quan, 2010b; Cai, Su, & Sattar, 2011).

3606 (Dinur & Safra, 2005), although one can achieve an approximation ratio of 2− o(1) (Halperin, 2002; Karakostas, 2005).
Recently, this conclusion has been enhanced that MC is not approximable within |V |1−ǫ for any ǫ > 0 unless NP=P (Zuckerman, 2006), derived from a derandomization of Håstad’s result.
Moreover, the currently best polynomial-time approximation algorithm for MC is only guaranteed to find a clique within a factor of O(n(loglogn)2/(logn)3) of optimum (Feige, 2004).

Exact methods which mainly include branch-and-bound algorithms (Carraghan & Pardalos, 1990; Fahle, 2002; Östergård, 2002; Régin, 2003; Tomita & Kameda, 2009; Li & Quan, 2010b, 2010a), guarantee the optimality of the solutions they find, but may fail to give a solution within reasonable time for large instances.

After that, a huge amount of effort was devoted to designing local search algorithms for MVC, MC and MIS problems (Aggarwal, Orlin, & Tai, 1997; Battiti & Protasi, 2001; Busygin, Butenko, & Pardalos, 2002; Shyu, Yin, & Lin, 2004; Barbosa & Campos, 2004; Pullan, 2006; Richter et al., 2007; Andrade, Resende, & Werneck, 2008; Cai et al., 2010, 2011).

After that, a huge amount of effort was devoted to designing local search algorithms for MVC, MC and MIS problems (Aggarwal, Orlin, & Tai, 1997; Battiti & Protasi, 2001; Busygin, Butenko, & Pardalos, 2002; Shyu, Yin, & Lin, 2004; Barbosa & Campos, 2004; Pullan, 2006; Richter et al., 2007; Andrade, Resende, & Werneck, 2008; Cai et al., 2010, 2011).
A review of heuristic algorithms for these three problems can be found in a recent paper on MVC local search (Cai et al., 2011).

First, they select a pair of vertices for exchanging simultaneously according to some heuristic (Richter et al., 2007; Cai et al., 2010, 2011), which is rather time-consuming, as will be explained in Section 3.
For example, COVER (Richter et al., 2007) increases weights of uncovered edges at each step, while EWLS (Cai et al.
, 2007) increases weights of uncovered edges at each step, while EWLS (Cai et al., 2010) and EWCC (Cai et al.
, 2010) and EWCC (Cai et al., 2011) increase weights of uncovered edges only when reaching local optima.

Indeed, the NuMVC algorithm utilizes a highly greedy heuristic for the removing stage, while for the adding stage, it makes good use of a diversifying heuristic within a framework similar to focused random walk (Papadimitriou, 1991).
We carry out a detailed experimental study to investigate the performance of NuMVC, and compare it with PLS (Pullan, 2006), COVER (Richter et al.
We carry out a detailed experimental study to investigate the performance of NuMVC, and compare it with PLS (Pullan, 2006), COVER (Richter et al., 2007) and EWCC (Cai et al.
, 2007) and EWCC (Cai et al., 2011), which are leading heuristic algorithms for MVC (MC, MIS).
For edge weighting local search, we follow the definitions and notations in EWCC (Cai et al., 2011).
For example, COVER selects a pair of vertices that maximize gain(u, v) (Richter et al., 2007), while EWLS (Cai et al.
, 2007), while EWLS (Cai et al., 2010) and EWCC (Cai et al.
, 2010) and EWCC (Cai et al., 2011) select a random pair of vertices with score(u, v) > 0.

Note that edge weighting techniques in MVC local search, including the one in this work, fall in the more general penalty idea for optimization problems, which dates back to Morris ’s breakout method (Morris, 1993) and has been widely used in local search algorithms for constraint optimization problems such as SAT (Yugami, Ohta, & Hara, 1994; Wu & Wah, 2000; Schuurmans, Southey, & Holte, 2001; Hutter, Tompkins, & Hoos, 2002).
For example, COVER (Richter et al., 2007) updates edge weights at each step, while EWLS (Cai et al.
, 2007) updates edge weights at each step, while EWLS (Cai et al., 2010) and EWCC (Cai et al.
, 2010) and EWCC (Cai et al., 2011) update edge weights only when reaching local optima.

According to the way that clause weights are smoothed, there are three main smoothing techniques in clause weighting local search algorithms for SAT to the best of our knowledge: the first is to pull all clause weights to their mean value using the formula wi := ρ · wi + (1 − ρ) · w, as in ESG (Schuurmans et al., 2001), SAPS (Hutter et al.

, 2001), SAPS (Hutter et al., 2002) and Swcca (Cai & Su, 2012); the second is to subtract one from all clause weights which are greater than one, as in DLM (Wu & Wah, 2000) and PAWS (Thornton, Pham, Bain, & Jr.

Recently, a forgetting mechanism was proposed for vertex weighting technique in the significant MC local search algorithm DLS-MC (Pullan & Hoos, 2006), which is an important sub-algorithm in PLS (Pullan, 2006) and CLS (Pullan, Mascia, & Brunato, 2011).
We also notice that the formula used in the forgetting mechanism in NuMVC has been adopted in long-term frequency-based learning mechanisms for tabu search (Taillard, 1994).
The CC strategy (Cai et al., 2011) was proposed for handling the
This strategy has been successfully applied in local search algorithms for MVC (Cai et al., 2011) as well as SAT (Cai & Su, 2011, 2012).
The CC strategy can be seen as a prohibition mechanism, which shares the same spirit but differs from the well-known prohibition mechanism called tabu (Glover, 1989).

Although being proposed two decades ago, the DIMACS benchmark remains the most popular benchmark and has been widely used for evaluating heuristic algorithms for MVC (Richter et al., 2007; Pullan, 2009; Cai et al., 2011; Gajurel & Bielefeld, 2012), MIS (Andrade et al.

, 2008; Pullan, 2009) and MC algorithms (Pullan, 2006; Katayama, Sadamatsu, & Narihisa, 2007; Grosso, Locatelli, & Pullan, 2008; Pullan et al., 2011; Wu, Hao, & Glover, 2012).
, 2008; Pullan, 2009) and MC algorithms (Pullan, 2006; Katayama, Sadamatsu, & Narihisa, 2007; Grosso, Locatelli, & Pullan, 2008; Pullan et al., 2011; Wu, Hao, & Glover, 2012).
The BHOSLIB benchmark is famous for its hardness and influential enough to be strongly recommended by the MVC (MC, MIS) community (Grosso et al., 2008; Cai et al., 2011).

Note that there are also parameters in other state-ofthe-art MVC (MC, MIS) algorithms, such as DLS-MC (Pullan & Hoos, 2006) and EWLS (Cai et al., 2010).
In the recent literature there are five leading heuristic algorithms for MVC (MC, MIS), including three MVC algorithms COVER (Richter et al., 2007), EWLS (Cai et al.
, 2007), EWLS (Cai et al., 2010) and EWCC (Cai et al.
, 2010) and EWCC (Cai et al., 2011), and two MC algorithms DLS-MC (Pullan & Hoos, 2006) and PLS (Pullan, 2006).

Finally, we would like to remark that the performance of NuMVC on the BHOSLIB benchmark is better than a four-core version of CLS (Pullan et al., 2011), even if we do not divide the run time of NuMVC by 4 (the number of cores utilized by CLS).

Compared toMVC andMIS, many more exact algorithms are designed for theMaximumClique problem (Carraghan & Pardalos, 1990; Fahle, 2002; Östergård, 2002; Régin, 2003; Tomita & Kameda, 2009; Li & Quan, 2010b, 2010a).

This normalization is based on the methodology established in the Second DIMACS Implementation Challenge for Cliques, Coloring, and Satisfiability, and is widely used for comparing different MaxClique algorithms (Pullan & Hoos, 2006; Pullan, 2006; Li & Quan, 2010b, 2010a).

The run time of the algorithm can be viewed as a random variable, which is fully described by its distribution, commonly referred to as the run-time distribution (RTD) in the literature about algorithm performance modeling (Hoos & Stützle, 2004; Bartz-Beielstein et al., 2010).

metadata.abstractText: The Minimum Vertex Cover (MVC) problem is a prominent NP-hard combinatorial optimization problem of great importance in both theory and application. Local search has proved successful for this problem. However, there are two main drawbacks in state-of-the-art MVC local search algorithms. First, they select a pair of vertices to exchange simultaneously, which is timeconsuming. Secondly, although using edge weighting techniques to diversify the search, these algorithms lack mechanisms for decreasing the weights. To address these issues, we propose two new strategies: two-stage exchange and edge weighting with forgetting. The two-stage exchange strategy selects two vertices to exchange separately and performs the exchange in two stages. The strategy of edge weighting with forgetting not only increases weights of uncovered edges, but also decreases some weights for each edge periodically. These two strategies are used in designing a new MVC local search algorithm, which is referred to as NuMVC. We conduct extensive experimental studies on the standard benchmarks, namely DIMACS and BHOSLIB. The experiment comparing NuMVC with state-of-the-art heuristic algorithms show that NuMVC is at least competitive with the nearest competitor namely PLS on the DIMACS benchmark, and clearly dominates all competitors on the BHOSLIB benchmark. Also, experimental results indicate that NuMVC finds an optimal solution much faster than the current best exact algorithm for Maximum Clique on random instances as well as some structured ones. Moreover, we study the effectiveness of the two strategies and the run-time behaviour through experimental analysis.
